metadata.title: Pulsed electrodeposition and mechanical properties of Ni-W/SiC nano-composite coatings

sections.text:
Contents lists available at ScienceDirect
Materials and Design
j ourna l homepage: www.e lsev ie r .com/ locate /matdes
Pulsed electrodeposition and mechanical properties of Ni-W/SiC nano-composite coatings
Nitin P. Wasekar a,⁎, S. Madhavi Latha a, M. Ramakrishna a, D.S. Rao a, G. Sundararajan a,b a International Advanced Research Centre for Powder Metallurgy and New Materials (ARCI), Hyderabad 500 005, India b Department of Metallurgical and Materials Engineering, Indian Institute of Technology Madras (IITM), Chennai 600 036, India
H I G H L I G H T S G R A P H I C A L A B S T R A C T
• Pulse parameters influence SiC content of Ni-W/SiC nanocomposite coatings. • Diffusion layer thickness acts as electrochemical mesh to filter oversized SiC particles. • Simplified mechanism of composite electrodeposition is proposed. • Grain size controls mechanical properties of nanocomposite above 5 vol.% SiC.
⁎ Corresponding author. E-mail address: nitin.arci@gmail.com (N.P. Wasekar).
http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.matdes.2016.09.070 0264-1275/© 2016 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
a b s t r a c t a r t i c l e i n f o
Article history: Received 18 March 2016 Received in revised form 16 September 2016 Accepted 19 September 2016 Available online 20 September 2016
Ni-W/SiC nanocomposite coatings were systematically deposited at varying pulse parameters and subsequently characterized using SEM, XRD, TEM for surface morphology, composition and SiC particle/Ni-Wmatrix interface phase boundary. In addition, mechanical properties of nanocomposite were also evaluated using nanoindentation. Uniform distribution of submicron SiC particles in nanocrystalline Ni-W alloy coatings was obtained using pulsed electrodeposition. The results indicated increase in SiC content of nanocrystalline Ni-W matrix with increase in pulse frequency and decrease in duty cycle. The incorporation of SiC was attributed to pulse current effect at cathode-solution interface leading to changes in pulsating diffusion layer thickness. A simplified mechanism of composite electrodeposition is proposed. The hardness and modulus of nanocomposite varied with SiC content. The variation in mechanical properties was rationalized based on rule of mixture and inverse Hall-Petch effect.
© 2016 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved. Keywords: Composite Plating Nickel tungsten Silicon carbide Hardness Metal matrix

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Metal matrix composite coatings have numerous special properties such as high strength, improved toughness due to dispersion hardening, high thermal stability, excellent wear and corrosion resistance.
Electrodeposition is one of themost economical techniques for depositing composite coatings. Pulsed current electroplating is a derivative of electrodeposition which can precisely control deposit properties at room temperature, attain rapid deposition rates and is affordable due to existing electroplating infrastructure. Therefore, in recent years, pulsed electrodeposition (PED) of composite coatings using hard particles dispersed in a metallic matrix is gaining wide importance in chemical, mechanical and electronic industries.
Since electrolytic hard chromium coatings are environmentally hazardous due to generation of hexavalent (Cr6+) chromium fume, a known carcinogen, Ni-W alloy electrodeposits are found to be suitable alternative to hard chromium (HCr). N-W alloy coatings possess high hardness (650–850 HV) in as deposited condition, excellent wear resistance compared to HCr [1], smooth surface finish and corrosion resistance to be used as protective coatings for glass moulding dies, oil pressurized parts, electrical connectors, engine valves, etc. Despite numerous applications, the composite consisting of Ni-W alloy matrix have been rarely explored with minimal attempts on pulsed electrodeposition of Ni-W/SiC nanocomposite coatings. The choice of SiC particles is due to its high hardness, oxidation resistance and high thermal stability.
Our earlier work [2] on influence of SiC content of electrolyte provided an insight into corrosion behavior of Ni-W/SiC nanocomposite coating suggesting improved corrosion resistance due to incorporation of SiC particles into Ni-W matrix due to formation of double layer of NiWO4 and SiO2 on coating surface when exposed to corrosive media. Yao et al. [3] illustrated improved wear and corrosion resistance of Ni-W/SiC nanocomposite coating with increase in SiC content of Ni-W matrix deposited using direct current electrodeposition.
As far as electrodeposition of Ni-W matrix composite is concerned, there exists few studies on Ni-W/diamond [4], Ni-W/TiO2 [5], Ni-W/ Al2O3 [6], Ni-W/WC [7], Ni-W/NaSiO3 [8], Ni-W/MWCNT [9], Ni-W/BN [10], Ni-W/MoS2 [11], Ni-W/ZrO2 [12] and recent work on Ni-W/ graphene oxide (GO) [13]. Most of the work is concerned on influence of particle concentration in plating electrolyte using direct current electrodeposition e.g. [14,15], subsequent composite coating characterization and performance evaluation. Since, the composite coating performance depends upon content and distribution of reinforcement particles, the direct current deposition can only vary content of particles by changing current density for a given concentration of particles in electrolyte. The above problem can be alleviated using pulsed current deposition which is known for microstructure and property control of nanocrystalline nickel coatings [16]. In composite coating electrodeposition, pulse current deposition offers option towards control of particle content aswell as distribution of particles by changing pulse parameters such as on time, off time (related to pulse frequency and duty cycle) and current density independently. In the view of above, Fan et al. [13] reported increase in graphene oxide content of Ni-W matrix with increase in pulse frequency for a given duty cycle. Similarly, Goldasteh and Rasegari [5] concluded, improvement in nano-TiO2 content of Ni-W matrix with increase in duty cycle. However, Thiemig et al. [6] presented a decrease in Al2O3 content of Ni matrix with increase in duty cycle contrary to the work of Chen et al. [17] on Ni-Al2O3 composite coatings. Thus, the influence of pulse parameters on particle content of electrodeposited composite coatings is still not clear. Therefore, the main aim of the present work is to study the detailed influence of pulse parameters such as duty cycle, pulse frequency on SiC content of nanocrystalline Ni-W alloy composite coating and its mechanical properties. The SiC content of Ni-W alloy coating and mechanical properties was rationalized based on influence of pulse parameters employed during electrodeposition and classical deformation mechanism.

sections.heading: 2.1. Pulsed electrodeposition of nanocomposite coatings
sections.text:
Ni-W/SiC coatings were electrodeposited using pulsed current on AISI 1045 mild steel substrate (60 × 60 × 5 mm) using Dynatronix (DPR 20-50-200) pulse power generator with experimental conditions as presented in Table 1. A square wave pulse current at various duty cycles was applied during deposition. Under direct current deposition, average current density (iavg) is the same as the peak current density (ip)
since the duty cycle (DC) (θ) is 100%. However, in PC deposition, the average current is given by,
iavg ¼ ip θ ð1Þ
Where, duty cycle θ is,
θ ¼ ton= ton þ toffð Þ ð2Þ
And pulse frequency, f,
f ¼ 1= ton þ toffð Þ ð3Þ
Where, ton, toff are cathodic on and off time respectively. Prior to coating, the mild steel coupons were cleaned as per ASTM B183-79. Electrodeposition was carried out using 3 l bath. The electrolyte composition for composite coatings is similar to our earlier work [1]. The β-SiC particles were employed as reinforcement phase. The SiC particle size distribution was obtained using Malvern particle size analyzer and is presented in Fig. 1. The SiC particle size is around 0.35 ± 0.15 μm. The temperature during electrodeposition and the quantity of SiC particles in electrolyte were maintained at 60 °C and 15 g/l respectively. No special treatment such as ultrasonication was given to composite electrolyte prior to electrodeposition.
Deposition was carried out for 1 h during all experiments. After deposition, the coatings were cleaned using distilled water and subsequently cut using electro discharge machining (EDM) for obtaining the samples for characterization and hardness tests. The current efficiency was calculated using theoretical mass deposited as per Faraday law and experimental mass deposited obtained from mass gain after completion of coating deposition [18]. This formula [18] considers the total mass of coating including SiC particles.

sections.heading: 2.2. Coating characterization
sections.text:
The coated samples were subjected to X-ray Diffractometer (D8-Advance, Brooker, Germany, Cu-Kα radiation, Bragg-Brentano geometry, 40 kV, 40 mA, 0.02/s scan rate) to estimate the crystallite size. The XRD grain (crystallite) size was estimated using the Scherrer relation [19],
d ¼ 0:93 λ= B cosθBð Þ ð4Þ
Where, d is the calculated average grain size of thematerial (A°);λ is the wavelength of radiation used (1.542 A°); θB is the Bragg angle (44.12°), B is the true broadening (radians). Generally, as the grain size of a material decreases below, the width of the X-ray diffraction peaks increases. This phenomenon is called peak broadening and is represented by B. The major factors influencing the peak broadening are grain refinement and instrumental effects. Therefore B is given by the following relation.
B ¼ √ BMð Þ2– BSð Þ2
ð5Þ
Where, BM is themeasured FWHM(FullWidthHalfMaximum), BS is the standard FWHM due to the equipment. FWHM is the measured in radians. A value of BS = 0.00872 rad, determined from the diffraction pattern of Ni powder with FWHM of the (111) peak under Cu Kα radiation (1.542 A°), was used to account for instrumental broadening. In case, where the peaks from substrate were present in diffraction pattern, the peaks were split using deconvolution technique using Origin software and peak broadening was measured. To further investigate the interface and grain size, in support of XRD, some of the coatings were subjected to transmission electron microscopy (TEM) analysis. The grain size was determined using FEI TECNAI 20G2-transmission electron microscope (TEM) and subsequent image analysis. Standard procedure was employed to obtain electron transparent Ni-W/SiC foil. A linear intercept method was employed to measure the grain size using Olympus Stream Essential software.
A scanning electron microscope (Hitachi Model S-4300SE/N, Japan) in conjunction with EDAX was employed for analyzing the coating surface morphology and elemental composition of coating. The volume fraction of SiC particles in Ni-W coatings after electrodeposition was estimated using SEMmicrographs. Assuming spherical SiC particles of diameter (DSiC) 0.35 μm, we derived the equation for volume fraction of reinforcement which can be given by,
Λ ¼ Dsic 2π=3 f sicð Þ–π=2ð Þ1=3–1 h i
ð6Þ
Where, Λ is inter-particle spacing and fsic is volume fraction of SiC particles in Ni-W matrix. The SEM micrographs (magnification: 5000×) of composite coatingswere analyzed under image analysis software (Olympus Stream Essential). For each micrograph, the distance between centre of neighboring and distinct SiC particles were noted manually using software. This exercise was followed for at least ten differentmicrographs taken at various locations across the coating. The average inter-particle spacingwas obtained for each deposition condition. Subsequently, using Eq. (6), the volume fraction (fsic) of SiC particles was calculated. The hardness and elastic modulus of as deposited coatingswasmeasured using CSMnanohardness tester at 25mN load as per Oliver-Pharr method [20]. The average of ten readings was reported from each coating. The size of indent was at least three times the inter-particle spacing of SiC particles in Ni-W matrix. A non contact 3- D optical profilometer (Scanning While Light Interferometry, Near View 6200, Zygo Corporation, Middlefield CT, USA) having a vertical scan range of 150 μm and a vertical resolution of b0.1 μm was utilized for the measurement of surface roughness of the coatings.

sections.heading: 3.1. Microstructure and SiC content of Ni-W/SiC nanocomposite
sections.text:
Microstructural features of Ni-W/SiC nanocomposite coatings at two extreme (10% and 80%) duty cycles for 10 and 100 Hz pulse frequency are presented in Figs. 2 and 3 respectively. In the same figure, the corresponding cross-sectional images of composite coating are also depicted. SEM micrographs demonstrate uniform distribution of SiC particles inside Ni-W alloy matrix. The particle agglomeration is not evident. Note that, the distribution of SiC particles is uniform across the coating cross section. As evident in Figs. 2 and 3, for higher SiC content, the coating thickness was found to be low as compared to lower SiC content (Table 2). This is due to current efficiency effect which is discussed in later part of this study. The coating thickness (±2 μm) surface roughness (Ra) (±0.05 μm) of coating is tabulated in Table 2. It is clear that, Ra values decrease with increase in duty cycle for a given frequency which is attributed to presence of SiC particles in Ni-W matrix. The higher the SiC, the higher would be the Ra of composite coatings. The composition analysis (line scan) of nanocomposite coatingwas also carried out in the cross section to validate the uniform composition ofW in surface and in the cross section as depicted in Fig. 2(e). The elemental analysis (Fig. 2(e–f)) suggests, uniform composition of Ni andW across the coating cross section as well as presence of SiC particles. The presence of SiC particles is indicated by arrows in each SEM micrograph. The corresponding EDS pattern is presented to confirm the presence of SiC particles in Figs. 2(f) and 3(e). It is clear from Fig. 4 in line with Figs. 2 and 3 that, the SiC reinforcement in Ni-W alloy coatings decreases with increase in duty cycle in agreement with the work of Thiemig et al. [6] for Ni-W/Al2O3 nanocomposite. In addition, for a given duty cycle, Ni-W/SiC nanocomposite demonstrated higher incorporation of SiC particles at higher pulse frequencies in contrast to the work of Boonyongmaneerat et al. [7] on Ni-W/WC composite coatings. Our earlier transmission electron microscopy results indicated excellent interface bonding between Ni-W matrix and SiC particles [2]. The quantity of SiC reinforcement obtained using Eq. (6) in nanocomposite coatings is shown in Fig. 4. As also evident in SEM micrographs, the volume fraction of SiC particles decreased with increase in duty cycle at all pulse frequencies. The highest quantity of SiC particles was around 7 vol.% deposited at 10% duty cycle (100 Hz) whereas lowest amount of SiC reinforcement was around 2.6 vol.% corresponding to 80% duty cycle and 10 Hz pulse frequency.
3.2. Current efficiency
The influence of pulse parameters on the current efficiency (CE) of Ni-W/SiC nanocomposite coating deposition is depicted in Fig. 5. The results indicate that, current efficiency increases with increase in duty cycle. For a given duty cycle, the current efficiency increases with decrease in pulse frequency. The change in current efficiency is attributed to SiC incorporation in Ni-Wmatrix. The behavior is discussed in detail in subsequent part of this study.

sections.heading: 3.3. Phase composition of Ni-W/SiC nanocomposite coatings
sections.text:
The X ray diffraction (XRD) pattern corresponding to as deposited Ni-W/SiC nanocomposite coatings on mild steel substrate for various duty cycles is presented in Fig. 6. Each diffraction pattern corresponds to Ni-W/SiC composite deposited at certain pulse frequency. The XRD pattern for standard Ni (JCPDS card number 00-004-0850) and Ni-W alloy without SiC has also been included for comparison purpose. A small peak observed at 2θ = 35.68° corresponds to (102) plane of SiC pattern (Fig. 6). In addition to Ni, the peak from substrate (AISI 1045 mild steel) is also evident (Fe-JCPDS card number 04-014-0360). NiW and pure Ni coatings are represented by FCC single phase peaks.
The Ni-W coating without SiC particle displays three sharp peaks at 2θ = 43.78°, 51.85° and 75.08° that corresponds to (111), (200) and (220) crystallographic face-centered cubic (FCC) planes of Ni respectively. This suggests that, Ni-W alloy coatings are single phase as observed by other investigators [21]. All the electrodeposited coatings resulted in broadening of respective peaks compared to their standard microcrystalline (JCPDS 00-004-0850) counterparts as observed in Fig. 6 suggesting nanocrystalline nature of these coatings. In presence of SiC, the (111) peak was more predominant while (200) and (220) peaks were found to be suppressed with the increase in pulse frequency. In addition, Ni diffraction peaks are shifted towards lower 2θ angle, compared to pure Ni peaks which could be attributed to the expansion of Ni lattice due to the incorporation ofWatomswith ~10% larger atomic radius than Ni atoms. A feature common to all diffraction patterns suggests that, peak broadening increases with increase in pulse frequency. The change in peak broadening is attributed to crystallite (grain) size of Ni-W/SiC nanocomposite coatings. The grain size
(crystallite size) of these coatings was calculated using Eq. (4) and is presented in Table 3. In general, the grain size in presence of SiC was lower than that of Ni-W coatings without SiC suggesting that SiC particles act as nucleating agents during electrodeposition. This is also evident from Fig. 6(a) wherein, the diffraction pattern corresponding to Ni-W/SiC nanocomposite is broader as compared to Ni-W alloy without SiC in the coating for similar W content. The W content of Ni-W/SiC nanocomposite coatings as a function of various pulse parameters was analyzed using energy dispersion spectroscopy (EDS) under SEM at five different locations within the coating. The average W content is presented in Table 4. Not much variation in W content with pulse parameters was observed. The results indicate that W content of coatings is 12 ± 1 at.% which is within solubility limit of W in Ni (12.5 at.%). In addition, the W content of composite was found to be uniform across the coating cross section and it was within 1% of surface composition. This is evident from elemental analysis of composite coating as presented in Fig. 2(e).

sections.heading: 3.4. Mechanical properties of Ni-W/SiC nanocomposite
sections.text: The mechanical properties of Ni-W/SiC nanocomposite coatings deposited at various pulse parameters were obtained using nano indentation technique. The results are presented in Fig. 7 as a function of vol.% of SiC reinforcement in Ni-W alloy matrix. For comparison purpose, Ni-W

alloy without SiC in coating is also presented. The hardness of Ni-W alloy without SiC was 8 ± 0.5 GPa, whereas modulus was 210 ± 10 GPa. The hardness increased by 25% whereas modulus increased by 20%when compared to Ni-W alloywithout SiCwith increase in SiC content up to 5 vol.% SiC. However, further increase in SiC content of Ni-W alloy lead to decrease in both hardness andmodulus of composite coating. The results indicate that there exists critical SiC content which results in decrease in mechanical properties of Ni-W/SiC composite coating. The rationale behind changes in mechanical properties is presented during discussion of experimental results.

sections.heading: 4. Discussion
sections.text:
First and foremost our results from Fig. 4 indicate a decrease in SiC content with increase in duty cycle while opposite was true for pulse frequency. Several studies [5,6,12] have presented similar results. The mechanism of co-deposition during electrodeposition in particular pulse current deposition of composite coating is still under extensive research and far from being concluded. Eroglue and West [22] presented mathematical model for Ni/SiC co-deposition and concluded that SiC
incorporation rate increases with the increase in resident time and number density of particles on the cathode surfacewhile it was inversely proportional to burial time of particles. The resident time is governed by toff while burial time depends upon ton during pulsed current electrodeposition.
This trend can be conferredwith the relation between duty cycle and pulse frequency from Eqs. (2) and (3),
θ ¼ ton f ð7Þ
The above relation suggests that for a constant pulse frequency, duty cycle increases with ton which happens only when toff is decreased as per Eq. (3). This indicates that, SiC particles do not have sufficient resident time to settle at cathode surface. As a result, SiC content of coating decreases. With another argument, for a constant duty cycle, the increase in pulse frequency can be achieved only by decrease in ton while increase in toff. This leads to longer resident time available for SiC particles resulting in increased incorporation of SiC in coating. Our results are in agreement with the work of Eroglue and West [22] and
several other investigators e.g. Thiemig et al. [6] for Ni-Al2O3 and CuAl2O3, Karathanasis et al. [23] for Ni-P/SiC, Lajevardi et al. [24] for NiAl2O3 and Gyftou et al. [25] for Ni-SiC system. However, above trend is more qualitative in nature although being true.

sections.heading: 4.1. Mechanism of particle Co-deposition
sections.text:
The mechanism of Ni-W alloy electrodeposition is called “Induced Co-deposition” since W can only be deposited in presence of iron group of metals (e.g. Fe, Ni). The mechanism is complex and discussed elsewhere [18]. In its simplest form, the process of electrodeposition of metal or its alloy takes place in three steps viz. ionic migration, electron transfer and incorporation. During first step, the hydrated ions of citrate complex of Ni and W migrate to cathode surface due to convection or under electric field influence through Nernst's diffusion layer (δN). The citrated complex is formed according to following reaction [18],
[(Ni) (Cit)]− + [(WO4) (Cit) (H)] 4− → [(Ni) (WO4) (Cit) (H)] 2− + Cit3−
Subsequently these ions enter the pulsating diffusion layer (δp) (Fig. 8) in second step thereby losing hydrated shell due to presence of higher electric field. In this step, the ion is neutralized by electron transfer and is adsorbed on cathode surface. In the last step, the adsorbed ion gets incorporated into crystal lattice after wandering on growth points.
With similar analogy, as per Guglielmi's [26] simplified model for composite electrodeposition, during first step in addition to the above metal ions there is the adsorption of citrate complex ions of Ni and W on the surface of a SiC particle. In the second stage, the migration of SiC particles with ionic cloud towards cathode surface through diffusion layers takes place. Here, these particles gets adsorbed thereby loosing hydrated shell by electron transfer reaction. Finally, the Ni and W atoms get incorporated into crystal lattice surrounding SiC particle. Thus, a SiC particle gets encapsulated in Ni-W alloy matrix.
Several modifications to the above model have been proposed. For example, Celis et al. [27] included the probabilistic approach for particle incorporation using five step model. Hwang [28] introduced one more step of forced convection of particles to cathode before two steps of Guglielmi and takes into account the reduction of adsorbed ions onto particle surface. The abovemodel has been furthermodified by Fransaer et al. [29] using particle trajectory and Bercot et al. [30] by considering hydrodynamics. Overall, all the models consider the particle transport to cathode surface.
We attribute, the major effect which controls the rate of particle incorporation into composite matrix, to how a particle being transported to the cathode surface through Nernst diffusion layer (δN) in case of direct current deposition and pulsating diffusion layer (δp) in case of pulse current electrodeposition before being incorporated. This is true since, in general, during electrodeposition, the metallic ions have to pass through these diffusion layers before being reduced at cathode surface. This is in linewith Celis et al. [27] workwhich states thatmass transport of particles to the cathode is proportional to the mass transport of ions.
Pulse current is known to modify the diffusion layer thickness as proposed by Ibl [31]. By proper selection of pulse current, ton, toff and the δp can be modified. A simplified view of concentration profile in analogy with Ibl [31] during pulsed electrodeposition is illustrated in Fig. 8. In case of co-deposition of Ni-W/SiC coatings, the concentration profile would be similar except in addition of metal ions, the SiC particles are also present. The concentration profile in immediate vicinity of cathode surface consists of pulsating diffusion layer of width = δp and Nernst diffusion layer of width= δN. Solid line Ce′-Ce″ (blue) represents concentration profile at the start of pulse while dashed line (black) represents concentration profile at time = ton + toff. In Gugliemi's model, the second step is a critical one where the particles get adsorbed at the growing coating surface. In this stage, the particles

are at pulsating diffusion layer (δp) in the case of pulsed electrodeposition, the thickness of which (δp) depends upon pulse parameters. Fortunately, the thickness/width of pulsating diffusion layer (δp) is independent of current density and bulkmetal ion concentration. However, it is just a function of ton during pulse current electrodeposition and diffusion coefficient (D) of metal ions in solution [31]. The relation is given by,
δp ¼ 2√ D ton=πð Þ ð8Þ
Upon using Eq. (7),
δp ¼ 2√ D θ= π fð Þð Þ ð9Þ
The above relation states that the thickness δp is directly proportional to the square root of duty cycle and inversely to the square root of pulse frequency. Our results indicate that, SiC content decreases with duty cycle for a given frequency while the opposite was true with respect to frequency for a given duty cycle. It suggests that there is a relation between δp and SiC content, since particles need to pass through this pulsating diffusion layer before being incorporated into coating. Using, the diffusion coefficient of metal ions in Ni-W alloy typically D ≈ 10−10 m2/s [32], the relation is presented in Fig. 9. It is clear that SiC content of Ni-W/SiC nanocomposite decreases with increase in δp and becomes independent of it after certain δp ~ 1.5 μmwhich is nearly
4 times the size of SiC particle size (0.35 μm). It is interesting to note that maximum incorporation of SiC particles occurred when δp = diameter of SiC particles (0.35 μm). An important implication of this relation is that the pulsating diffusion layer acts as an electrochemical filter or mesh such that the particles having size equal to or less than diffusion layer thickness will get incorporated into growing matrix to the maximum extent.
The above results are in agreementwith thework of Vereecken et al. [33] which suggested that the particle size should be smaller than diffusion layer thickness in Ni-Al2O3 system for 0.3 μm Al2O3 particle size to achieve maximum particle incorporation. On similar line, Podlaha and Landolt [34] observed that maximum particle concentration was found when rate of metal deposited per unit cycle is equal to Al2O3 particle diameter in Cu-Al2O3 system using pulse reverse current plating which was achieved using decrease in duty cycle. Our study indicates that proper selection of pulse parameter in particular ton can lead to higher incorporation of inert particles in metallic matrix. The study on several combinations of inert particles, its size and metallic matrix is currently under active perusal.
As far as current efficiency (CE) is concerned, our result indicates that it increasedwith increase in duty cycle and decreasedwith increase in pulse frequency.We attribute the decrease in current efficiency to the presence of SiC particles as shown in Fig. 10(a). It is very clear that CE decreased linearlywith increase in SiC content of coatings. Interestingly, the extrapolated CE value matches exactly with CE (28%) during Ni-W
ating deposition (Schematic). C0 – bulk metal ion concentration, Ce′ – Concentration at
alloy deposition without SiC. It has been observed that deposition rate decreases in the presence of inert particle [35], therefore, for higher SiC content; the coating thickness was found to be lower as evident in Figs. 2 and 3. Watson [36] concluded in electrochemical study of SiC particle occlusion during Ni/SiC electrodeposition that, SiC particles catalyze the formation of H(ads) thereby reducing the current efficiency since the current applied is now also utilized for hydrogen evolution.

sections.heading: 4.2. Mechanical properties
sections.text:
The mechanical properties of Ni-W/SiC nanocomposite coatings (Fig. 7) were found to be improved as compared to Ni-W alloy (HNiW = 8 GPa, ENi-W = 210 GPa) without SiC present in matrix for similar W content. The increase inmeasured hardness andmodulus of composite coating is attributed to incorporation of SiC particles and grain size refining due to the presence of SiC particles in Ni-W alloy matrix. The strengthening due to Orowan dispersion hardening mechanism is ruled out in the present study since SiC particle size was much larger than the grain size of Ni-W alloy matrix. The strengthening due to SiC
Fig. 10. Variation in current efficiency (a) and grain size (b) of Ni-W/SiC nanocom
particles can be obtained by rule of mixture. Thus the composite hardness and modulus can be written as,
HNi−W=SiC ¼ f SiC:HSiC þ 1– f SiCð Þ:HNi−W ð10Þ
ENi−W=SiC ¼ f SiC:ESiC þ 1– f SiCð Þ:ENi−W ð11Þ
In this case, HSiC and ESiC are 25 GPa and 430 GPa respectively. Upon substitution of these values in Eqs. (10) and (11), the hardness and modulus of composite are presented in Fig. 7 as solid line. The results are in agreement with composite model. However, both hardness and modulus of composite were found to decrease above ~5 vol.% SiC in coatings. We attribute this decrease to grain refining effect due to the presence of SiC in composite. The presence of inert particles is known to refine grain size during co-deposition since they act as nucleating agents for grain refinement [37]. It is evident from Fig. 10(b) wherein grain size is presented against SiC content of coating for different duty cycles. The grain size initially remains constant at 5±1 nmwith change in SiC content. However, substantial grain refining is observed above 5 vol.% SiC in coating. In order to get further insight into mechanical properties, the grain size is plotted against hardness as per classical Hall-Petch [38] plot in Fig. 11. As evident in Fig. 10, the grain size is
posite coatings as a function of SiC content deposited at different duty cycles.
much below Hall-Petch inflection (breakdown) point which is ~10 nm [1,21] for Ni-W alloy as presented in Fig. 11. For Ni-W alloy (without SiC)with grain size of 10 nm, the corresponding hardness (at inflection) is 8 GPa. The Hall-Petch breakdown is attributed to diffusional mechanism such as Cobel creep or grain boundary sliding [39,40]. Note that, the Hall-Petch inflection point is decreased to much lower grain size (~5 nm). Such a decrease is attributed to presence of SiC particles in Ni-W alloy matrix which restrain the deformation mechanism (Cobel creep/grain boundary sliding) at finest grain size below inflection. The decrease in hardness above 5 vol.% SiC is thus attributed to inverse Hall-Petch effect. The grain size (b4 nm) contribution to hardness is more than the presence of SiC particles above 5 vol.% SiC. The change in modulus is also related to grain size refinement (below 5 nm) due to the presence of high intercrystalline region and triple junctions. For example, Zhao et al. [41] and Zhou et al. [42] reported large reduction in elastic modulus with grain size (b4 nm) in electrodeposited Ni and Ni-P alloy due to the significant interface contributions at very small grain size for nanocrystalline Ni–P alloys [42] which was ascribed to sharp increase in triple junction volume fraction below 4 nm grain size.
The mechanical properties of composite coatings also depend upon density and uniformity of composite coatings [43] which is governed by interface between SiC particles and Ni-Wmatrix. The cross-sectional view of composite coatings clearly depicts uniform distribution of SiC particles (Figs. 2–3). Our earlier results demonstrated excellent interfacial bonding between SiC particles and Ni-W matrix using TEM studies [2]. To further investigate the interface and grain size, in support of XRD, some of the coatings were subjected to transmission electron microscopy (TEM) analysis. The TEMmicrograph depictingNi-W/SiC composite coating obtained at 80% DC, 25 Hz frequency is presented along with selected area diffraction pattern (SAED) of Ni-W matrix and EDS analysis of SiC particle in Fig. 12. The grain size of Ni-W/SiC composite was estimated to 7.2 ± 1.3 nmwhich is in agreement with XRD results (5.39 nm). The SAED pattern also confirms predominant (111) plane of single phaseNi-Walloy as observed in XRDpattern (Fig. 6). EDS analysis of SiC particle (Fig. 12(b)) is also in agreementwith SEM analysis. In addition, the interface between SiC particle and Ni-Wmatrix was found to be devoid of cracks or voids indicating excellent interface bonding.
Thus improvement in strength and modulus is attributed to strong interface bonding between SiC particles and Ni-W alloy matrix at least up to 5 vol.%. However, above 5 vol.% SiC, the interface (grain boundaries, triple junctions) might be the contributing factor for coating density thereby leading to changes in mechanical properties. In a recent study, Beltowska-Lehman [44] also observed the decrease in hardness of Ni-W/ZrO2 coatings above 5 wt.% ZrO2 which is in agreement with the present work.
In conclusion, given the high hardness of Ni-W/SiC coatings (~8– 10 GPa), these coatings can be suitable alternative for hard chrome
replacement for wear and corrosion resistance application. The wear and corrosion behavior study of Ni-W/SiC coatings in comparison with hard chrome is under active perusal at the author's laboratory.

sections.heading: 5. Conclusions
sections.text:
Ni-W/SiC nanocomposite coatings were systematically deposited by varying pulse parameters during pulse current electrodeposition. The major conclusions drawn from present study are as follows.
(1) SiC content of Ni-W/SiC nanocomposite coatings decreases with increase in duty cycle for a given pulse frequency. In contrast, for a given duty cycle SiC content of coatings increases with increase in pulse frequency. (2) The incorporation of SiC particles in Ni-W alloy matrix depends upon the thickness of pulsating diffusion layer. Maximum incorporation of SiC occurred in coating when the thickness of pulsating diffusion layer was equal to SiC particle size (0.35 μm). (3) Hardness and modulus of Ni-W/SiC nanocomposite coatings increased with increase in SiC content as per rule of mixtures and subsequently decreased above 5 vol.% SiC. (4) The decrease in mechanical properties (above 5 vol.% SiC) is attributed to grain size refinement due to the presence of SiC particles during electrodeposition. The resultant grain size was always below Hall-Petch inflection point leading to decreased mechanical properties of Ni-W/SiC nanocomposite coatings above 5 vol.% SiC.

referenceMentions.context: N-W alloy coatings possess high hardness (650–850 HV) in as deposited condition, excellent wear resistance compared to HCr [1], smooth surface finish and corrosion resistance to be used as protective coatings for glass moulding dies, oil pressurized parts, electrical connectors, engine valves, etc.

Our earlier work [2] on influence of SiC content of electrolyte provided an insight into corrosion behavior of Ni-W/SiC nanocomposite coating suggesting improved corrosion resistance due to incorporation of SiC particles into Ni-W matrix due to formation of double layer of NiWO4 and SiO2 on coating surface when exposed to corrosive media.
[3] illustrated improved wear and corrosion resistance of Ni-W/SiC nanocomposite coating with increase in SiC content of Ni-W matrix deposited using direct current electrodeposition.

As far as electrodeposition of Ni-W matrix composite is concerned, there exists few studies on Ni-W/diamond [4], Ni-W/TiO2 [5], Ni-W/ Al2O3 [6], Ni-W/WC [7], Ni-W/NaSiO3 [8], Ni-W/MWCNT [9], Ni-W/BN [10], Ni-W/MoS2 [11], Ni-W/ZrO2 [12] and recent work on Ni-W/ graphene oxide (GO) [13].

As far as electrodeposition of Ni-W matrix composite is concerned, there exists few studies on Ni-W/diamond [4], Ni-W/TiO2 [5], Ni-W/ Al2O3 [6], Ni-W/WC [7], Ni-W/NaSiO3 [8], Ni-W/MWCNT [9], Ni-W/BN [10], Ni-W/MoS2 [11], Ni-W/ZrO2 [12] and recent work on Ni-W/ graphene oxide (GO) [13].

As far as electrodeposition of Ni-W matrix composite is concerned, there exists few studies on Ni-W/diamond [4], Ni-W/TiO2 [5], Ni-W/ Al2O3 [6], Ni-W/WC [7], Ni-W/NaSiO3 [8], Ni-W/MWCNT [9], Ni-W/BN [10], Ni-W/MoS2 [11], Ni-W/ZrO2 [12] and recent work on Ni-W/ graphene oxide (GO) [13].

As far as electrodeposition of Ni-W matrix composite is concerned, there exists few studies on Ni-W/diamond [4], Ni-W/TiO2 [5], Ni-W/ Al2O3 [6], Ni-W/WC [7], Ni-W/NaSiO3 [8], Ni-W/MWCNT [9], Ni-W/BN [10], Ni-W/MoS2 [11], Ni-W/ZrO2 [12] and recent work on Ni-W/ graphene oxide (GO) [13].

As far as electrodeposition of Ni-W matrix composite is concerned, there exists few studies on Ni-W/diamond [4], Ni-W/TiO2 [5], Ni-W/ Al2O3 [6], Ni-W/WC [7], Ni-W/NaSiO3 [8], Ni-W/MWCNT [9], Ni-W/BN [10], Ni-W/MoS2 [11], Ni-W/ZrO2 [12] and recent work on Ni-W/ graphene oxide (GO) [13].

As far as electrodeposition of Ni-W matrix composite is concerned, there exists few studies on Ni-W/diamond [4], Ni-W/TiO2 [5], Ni-W/ Al2O3 [6], Ni-W/WC [7], Ni-W/NaSiO3 [8], Ni-W/MWCNT [9], Ni-W/BN [10], Ni-W/MoS2 [11], Ni-W/ZrO2 [12] and recent work on Ni-W/ graphene oxide (GO) [13].

As far as electrodeposition of Ni-W matrix composite is concerned, there exists few studies on Ni-W/diamond [4], Ni-W/TiO2 [5], Ni-W/ Al2O3 [6], Ni-W/WC [7], Ni-W/NaSiO3 [8], Ni-W/MWCNT [9], Ni-W/BN [10], Ni-W/MoS2 [11], Ni-W/ZrO2 [12] and recent work on Ni-W/ graphene oxide (GO) [13].

As far as electrodeposition of Ni-W matrix composite is concerned, there exists few studies on Ni-W/diamond [4], Ni-W/TiO2 [5], Ni-W/ Al2O3 [6], Ni-W/WC [7], Ni-W/NaSiO3 [8], Ni-W/MWCNT [9], Ni-W/BN [10], Ni-W/MoS2 [11], Ni-W/ZrO2 [12] and recent work on Ni-W/ graphene oxide (GO) [13].

Pulse current is known to modify the diffusion layer thickness as proposed by Ibl [31].
A simplified view of concentration profile in analogy with Ibl [31] during pulsed electrodeposition is illustrated in Fig.
However, it is just a function of ton during pulse current electrodeposition and diffusion coefficient (D) of metal ions in solution [31].

On similar line, Podlaha and Landolt [34] observed that maximum particle concentration was found when rate of metal deposited per unit cycle is equal to Al2O3 particle diameter in Cu-Al2O3 system using pulse reverse current plating which was achieved using decrease in duty cycle.
It has been observed that deposition rate decreases in the presence of inert particle [35], therefore, for higher SiC content; the coating thickness was found to be lower as evident in Figs.

Watson [36] concluded in electrochemical study of SiC particle occlusion during Ni/SiC electrodeposition that, SiC particles catalyze the formation of H(ads) thereby reducing the current efficiency since the current applied is now also utilized for hydrogen evolution.
The presence of inert particles is known to refine grain size during co-deposition since they act as nucleating agents for grain refinement [37].
In order to get further insight into mechanical properties, the grain size is plotted against hardness as per classical Hall-Petch [38] plot in Fig.

The Hall-Petch breakdown is attributed to diffusional mechanism such as Cobel creep or grain boundary sliding [39,40].

[42] reported large reduction in elastic modulus with grain size (b4 nm) in electrodeposited Ni and Ni-P alloy due to the significant interface contributions at very small grain size for nanocrystalline Ni–P alloys [42] which was ascribed to sharp increase in triple junction volume fraction below 4 nm grain size.

[42] reported large reduction in elastic modulus with grain size (b4 nm) in electrodeposited Ni and Ni-P alloy due to the significant interface contributions at very small grain size for nanocrystalline Ni–P alloys [42] which was ascribed to sharp increase in triple junction volume fraction below 4 nm grain size.
The mechanical properties of composite coatings also depend upon density and uniformity of composite coatings [43] which is governed by interface between SiC particles and Ni-Wmatrix.
Our earlier results demonstrated excellent interfacial bonding between SiC particles and Ni-W matrix using TEM studies [2].
In a recent study, Beltowska-Lehman [44] also observed the decrease in hardness of Ni-W/ZrO2 coatings above 5 wt.

metadata.abstractText: • Pulse parameters influence SiC content of Ni-W/SiC nanocomposite coatings. • Diffusion layer thickness acts as electrochemical mesh to filter oversized SiC particles. • Simplified mechanism of composite electrodeposition is proposed. • Grain size controls mechanical properties of nanocomposite above 5 vol.% SiC. ⁎ Corresponding author.
